componenttext: Okay. That sounds great. And then have there been any changes in the customer ordering patterns? I mean, is it really just sort of consumer takeaway or are your customers getting a little bit more conservative in terms of planning since your warehouse model?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hubert?
componenttext: Hubert?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: What we’re seeing is there’s probably more treats that with an average basket which is decreasing. This is nothing new; that is something which has been the case for at least 18 to 2 years. We're responding to that with new promotional scheme on top o
componenttext: What we’re seeing is there’s probably more treats that with an average basket which is decreasing. This is nothing new; that is something which has been the case for at least 18 to 2 years. We're responding to that with new promotional scheme on top of the 6 pack in 1.5 we offer duo pack, 2 bottles. We’re also entering Iced Tea with a new format, a new package with 375 ml, which in GB would come on shelf at 89p as oppose to 108 for the 500. But there is some shift in the consumption pattern of the consumer, but frankly the main effect this quarter was really the weather.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I double checked while Hubert was answering, and Trademark Coke was down approximately 6% roughly in line with the overall volume trends.
componenttext: I double checked while Hubert was answering, and Trademark Coke was down approximately 6% roughly in line with the overall volume trends.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: That’s really helpful. And then what's the magic of the 65 million share authorization. Is that just a board decision and could that be upped if you guys had a board meeting and decided you wanted to buy back more stock because when I look at it, you ha
componenttext: That’s really helpful. And then what's the magic of the 65 million share authorization. Is that just a board decision and could that be upped if you guys had a board meeting and decided you wanted to buy back more stock because when I look at it, you had 375 million, I guess for the first-half of the year, so if your run rate that it’s like 750 million, so is there any real magic to that 65 million share authorization?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: There was some logic to it Bill. When we did the original transaction we set a cap of 20% which we rounded at 65 million shares from that time for about a 2-year period. So that effectively takes us to Q1 of 2000 -- sorry October 1, 2012. We’ve kind of
componenttext: There was some logic to it Bill. When we did the original transaction we set a cap of 20% which we rounded at 65 million shares from that time for about a 2-year period. So that effectively takes us to Q1 of 2000 -- sorry October 1, 2012. We’ve kind of rolled that forward to the end of the year. So that’s where the origin of that 65 million share number comes from. But that would not be an inhibitor prospectively after that 2-year moratorium has passed.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Lauren Torres of HSBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Lauren Torres of HSBC.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure, did you mention for the quarter what the total company future versus immediate consumption trends were?
componenttext: I'm not sure, did you mention for the quarter what the total company future versus immediate consumption trends were?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, we didn’t. We can make some broad comments upon that. Hubert you want to talk a little bit about that?
componenttext: No, we didn’t. We can make some broad comments upon that. Hubert you want to talk a little bit about that?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, the trend was slightly more negative for the single serve which we would characterize as Iced Tea. Clearly again driven by the weather but we’re having some good initiative in this area and I am pleased to report that we have achieved our record ma
componenttext: Yes, the trend was slightly more negative for the single serve which we would characterize as Iced Tea. Clearly again driven by the weather but we’re having some good initiative in this area and I am pleased to report that we have achieved our record market share in immediate consumption in GB with the launch of the 375 ml, but overall the cans, the single cans and the small PT were lagging behind the rest of the market. So single serve were more negative than -- which is normal when you have, you don’t open the outside of your new cafe and things like that.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just keep in mind Lauren, we’ve mentioned this before. One of the things that is, encouraging about the business model we have here in Europe is that, when swings like that do occur and in times of economic challenge or bad weather, people are not going
componenttext: Just keep in mind Lauren, we’ve mentioned this before. One of the things that is, encouraging about the business model we have here in Europe is that, when swings like that do occur and in times of economic challenge or bad weather, people are not going out as much and on-the-go consumption tends to get impacted. The fact is, from a profitability standpoint our business model is robust and that we make almost as much money and perhaps even as much money in future consumption as we do in immediate consumption and of course that’s not the case in certain other markets around the world.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess with that said, do you think there's less room for pricing? It seems like there is a little bit of pushback on the consumer side, you’ve been able to cover your cost of pricing and if the consumers' maybe getting a little directionally
componenttext: Okay. And I guess with that said, do you think there's less room for pricing? It seems like there is a little bit of pushback on the consumer side, you’ve been able to cover your cost of pricing and if the consumers' maybe getting a little directionally softer, is there less room to take that price hike that you were planning?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we strongly believe and we prove it with our category vision world, which shows that there is an additional potential for turnaround of $4.6 billion in all our European territory. So the potential for additional revenue is that. Having said that,
componenttext: I think we strongly believe and we prove it with our category vision world, which shows that there is an additional potential for turnaround of $4.6 billion in all our European territory. So the potential for additional revenue is that. Having said that, tax in pricing, taxing tariff in our territory is always a tough negotiation with the trade. We have managed to have it in all our BUs in due time and we’re also sensible to the consumer demands. So it’s a balancing act between the price increase and the promotional spending and that the way we are really making trade-off with one single priority which is to deliver on our guidance on the OI level.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just to remind you Lauren about the timing of our pricing; we take pricing in GB and France in the early part of the year so that’s already been effected with our customers and then Benelux would be more in the early fall and that process is already und
componenttext: Just to remind you Lauren about the timing of our pricing; we take pricing in GB and France in the early part of the year so that’s already been effected with our customers and then Benelux would be more in the early fall and that process is already underway. So for 2012 I think the concern is minimal, not to comment but I think the concern would be more in 2013, but I think we feel pretty confident that we’ll be able to -- that we have or will be able to garner the pricing that we need for 2012.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Powers of Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Powers of Bernstein.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And back to weather for a second, weather was undeniably poor in Q2, but how confident are you, it sounds like you’re pretty confident in the underlying demand situation. How are you assessing that and has anything changed in what you’re tracking in r
componenttext: And back to weather for a second, weather was undeniably poor in Q2, but how confident are you, it sounds like you’re pretty confident in the underlying demand situation. How are you assessing that and has anything changed in what you’re tracking in recent months whether positive or negative as you look forward?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I’ll make a couple of comments on that and say that frankly we think our business model still works. This weather we’ve been through over the last -- really 4 months now, 3.5 months to 4 months, has just been the worst imaginable and I'm not sure if y
componenttext: I’ll make a couple of comments on that and say that frankly we think our business model still works. This weather we’ve been through over the last -- really 4 months now, 3.5 months to 4 months, has just been the worst imaginable and I'm not sure if you’ve heard the same thing from everybody else in the business. So we’ll see, it’s been so bad that honestly and we would say it’s meaningfully more than half the issue. It is hard having said that to dissect all the other components, I mean, clearly there are macroeconomic issues out there, the consumer fragility issues, but our sense is that, the basic value creation model we have remains in place and that with some normal weather and you add to it the kind of programs we have in place for the third and fourth quarter, we’re optimistic. But we’ll see, with some normal weather we’re going to be in a much better position to be able to kind of decipher exactly what's going on with some of these other issues and frankly to see whether they’re really issues or not.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: You also say that French sales tax is a headwind in the quarter. Could you give us an update on how demand is trending in France and how retailers have been reacting to the tax since the last update you provided?
componenttext: You also say that French sales tax is a headwind in the quarter. Could you give us an update on how demand is trending in France and how retailers have been reacting to the tax since the last update you provided?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me ask Hubert to do that.
componenttext: Sure. Let me ask Hubert to do that.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we said, of course France was also impacted by the bad weather. As John said, difficult to dissect all the other factors in the decrease, but the excise tax is clearly a headwind and has negatively impacted we think our volume growth. As you remem
componenttext: Yes. As we said, of course France was also impacted by the bad weather. As John said, difficult to dissect all the other factors in the decrease, but the excise tax is clearly a headwind and has negatively impacted we think our volume growth. As you remember we took out the tax-related price increase as of January 1, and we are adding that our own tariff increase. Year-to-date we have seen the pricing increase on the shelf in France as customers have strategically chosen to pass that increase to consumer, but they have done that on various timelines and frankly it varies by channel and it varies by pack. And today it doesn’t reflect the full impact of the tax and our tariff combine. But we still think that the elasticity of our product should in some way moderate the impact of the tariff increase. So it’s not fully impacted yet. We need to wait for full quarter with the full impact of the tariff, it varies by customer. Overall, its 4% to 5% price increase for the moment. So again, it’s not the full impact and we will see. But again the major factor also for France was the bad weather.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. And do you expect that full quarter or full impact to be Q3, is it Q4, or is it not till next year?
componenttext: Great. And do you expect that full quarter or full impact to be Q3, is it Q4, or is it not till next year?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: It’s difficult to say because clearly some customers are playing strategically as a way to position theirselves in this current environment, which is in more intense competition especially with the bad weather or clearly the category was not growing. So
componenttext: It’s difficult to say because clearly some customers are playing strategically as a way to position theirselves in this current environment, which is in more intense competition especially with the bad weather or clearly the category was not growing. So it maybe Q3, but I am not 100% assertive on that one.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then maybe just lastly, a question for Bill, obviously the environment is difficult, lack of visibility and you’ve had to take care your free cash flow forecast down. How are you thinking about your capital structure in leverage of particular medi
componenttext: Okay. Then maybe just lastly, a question for Bill, obviously the environment is difficult, lack of visibility and you’ve had to take care your free cash flow forecast down. How are you thinking about your capital structure in leverage of particular medium term, are you still comfortable levering the balance sheet up back up to the target range next year even if the macroenvironment doesn’t stabilize and what if anything would change that, that stance?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well I just comment on the free cash flow and the other changes that we made. The majority of that impact was currency. So the underlying business had marginal impact on that revised guidance. It was principally currency. And then the second part of
componenttext: Sure. Well I just comment on the free cash flow and the other changes that we made. The majority of that impact was currency. So the underlying business had marginal impact on that revised guidance. It was principally currency. And then the second part of your question Steve is, we remain committed to utilizing our balance sheet and would think that we would be able to get within that targeted range by the end of 2013. At a minimum we will have a plan that we’ll articulate hopefully on our outlook call in December of this year. So overall, fundamentally our view and confidence in utilizing that balance sheet capacity has not changed.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kaumil Gajrawala of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kaumil Gajrawala of UBS.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: If I could also follow-up on the 65 billion share cap or maybe more importantly what comes after that, is there any change or adjustment in how you’re thinking about cash return to shareholders will still be largely buyback or maybe would there be a shi
componenttext: If I could also follow-up on the 65 billion share cap or maybe more importantly what comes after that, is there any change or adjustment in how you’re thinking about cash return to shareholders will still be largely buyback or maybe would there be a shift over to with a little bit more focus on dividend versus buyback, any changes there?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Kaumil, Bill here. We’re committed and remain committed as I just mentioned on the prior question to returning cash to shareowners. The form and timing of that I think is to be decided and to be communicated and we would envision doing that most likely
componenttext: Kaumil, Bill here. We’re committed and remain committed as I just mentioned on the prior question to returning cash to shareowners. The form and timing of that I think is to be decided and to be communicated and we would envision doing that most likely in the December outlook call.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then from -- if I could ask, and I know you’ve gotten plenty of questions on the weather, but you seem quite confident that during periods of time where the weather was more favorable, your trends were a bit stronger, is there any specific numbers o
componenttext: And then from -- if I could ask, and I know you’ve gotten plenty of questions on the weather, but you seem quite confident that during periods of time where the weather was more favorable, your trends were a bit stronger, is there any specific numbers or spread that you were able to see between what the quarter looked like and what things looked like when the weather was a little bit better?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Candidly, Kaumil, I think it’s just -- it’s too difficult to tell. I mean frankly, we haven’t had that many periods of good weather to look at it, but we have had an isolated week here and there where things have been a bit better. But no, we’re n
componenttext: Candidly, Kaumil, I think it’s just -- it’s too difficult to tell. I mean frankly, we haven’t had that many periods of good weather to look at it, but we have had an isolated week here and there where things have been a bit better. But no, we’re not that scientific -- kind of wish we were but we're not, and we’re -- all we’re hoping for is a return to normal weather and if we get that, we’ll be fine.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then last question on energy, it looks like from the first quarter there was a pretty big sequential slowdown in the growth rate, however, obviously the comp is much more difficult, is there anything going on inside of that, that you wanted to highlig
componenttext: And then last question on energy, it looks like from the first quarter there was a pretty big sequential slowdown in the growth rate, however, obviously the comp is much more difficult, is there anything going on inside of that, that you wanted to highlight?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hubert?
componenttext: Hubert?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Again, energy, even if it’s still growing it’s not immune from the bad weather, there is still an impact, in fact as a category it’s normally more seasonal than the rest of the soft drinks, so it’s no surprise that it slowed down. But we’re seei
componenttext: Again, energy, even if it’s still growing it’s not immune from the bad weather, there is still an impact, in fact as a category it’s normally more seasonal than the rest of the soft drinks, so it’s no surprise that it slowed down. But we’re seeing -- I think we’re continuously seeing the success of our multi-brand strategy with a lot of traction behind the brand, and with the majority of the growth coming from Monster.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: It’s Jude. First, just in terms of the competitive environment I know the first part of the year your competitor was a lot more promotional, so maybe if you can just update on kind of what you’re seeing as you’ve a lot more activation now in the mar
componenttext: It’s Jude. First, just in terms of the competitive environment I know the first part of the year your competitor was a lot more promotional, so maybe if you can just update on kind of what you’re seeing as you’ve a lot more activation now in the marketplace. And then do you envision any benefits from Britvic’s product recall issue in terms of either gaining some share in some of the products that you overlap or just in terms of their focus maybe now fixing that issue as supposed to other category that you’ve a broader overlap with?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Judy, is your question GB specific?
componenttext: Judy, is your question GB specific?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: It’s GB -- more so GB, but maybe just broadly about the -- just the competitive and the promotional environment, as well.
componenttext: It’s GB -- more so GB, but maybe just broadly about the -- just the competitive and the promotional environment, as well.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, let me comment on the second question and then I’ll ask Hubert to come in on the first one. And in terms of the recall, clearly we’ve got a platform, a portfolio of products, which appeal to a wide variety of consumers and you can assume that an
componenttext: Well, let me comment on the second question and then I’ll ask Hubert to come in on the first one. And in terms of the recall, clearly we’ve got a platform, a portfolio of products, which appeal to a wide variety of consumers and you can assume that any time there is any kind of a dislocation in the marketplace, obviously we’d want to make sure that everybody knows our products are available and we’ll do what we can do to make sure the consumers get some of their choices filled. Capri-Sun particularly is a nice product that kind of plays in that same category, but I think other than that, just to say, our team is going to be out there pushing hard trying to make sure that our customers and our consumers have what they need. On the competitive set, let me ask Hubert to comment on that.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: In GB, like in other territory we see the category as being expandable and a value-creation category. And regularly we see period of planned promotional activity and as you stated the first half of the year has been no different, it has been quite heavy i
componenttext: In GB, like in other territory we see the category as being expandable and a value-creation category. And regularly we see period of planned promotional activity and as you stated the first half of the year has been no different, it has been quite heavy in term of competitive activity, to say the truth especially through the end of the quarter. Possibly influenced by the weather our marketing calendar, which is not in full swing, was more aided into the Olympics and more aided into July-August. What we now expect for the second half of the year is a more rational pricing environment. We have taken our price increase, as has been stated, in the beginning of the year and listening to our competitor Britvic in the earnings call they have mentioned that they’re planning to take price as of May and June. So, we think the pricing environment to be more rational -- to be rational for the second half of the year and while we are going to have our Olympic program especially in action.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just following up on energy, can you update us on just how POWERADE Energy is doing now that it’s been in the market for about a year? And then, I know you were talking about Rehab gaining distribution this year, so just in terms of how t
componenttext: Okay. And then just following up on energy, can you update us on just how POWERADE Energy is doing now that it’s been in the market for about a year? And then, I know you were talking about Rehab gaining distribution this year, so just in terms of how that’s progressing as well?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. POWERADE Energy is clearly an extension of the brand POWERADE. This year, our focus is more about POWERADE as a sports drink. So we’re packing the launch with the shift of our focus probably more towards POWERADE as a sports drink. If we look at th
componenttext: Yes. POWERADE Energy is clearly an extension of the brand POWERADE. This year, our focus is more about POWERADE as a sports drink. So we’re packing the launch with the shift of our focus probably more towards POWERADE as a sports drink. If we look at the global portfolio for energy, as I said, really for the moment, Monster is leading our growth and we’ve some good reaction to the introduction of the new SKUs I mentioned, especially Rehab. So we’re really encouraged by the traction we’re seeing beyond our innovation, and as I said the energy was growing still 8% -- 16% and we expect more for this quarter.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions, or follow-up questions I guess related to the outlook. Bill, the change in CapEx guidance, is that also just foreign exchange effects the translation of the CapEx?
componenttext: Just a couple of questions, or follow-up questions I guess related to the outlook. Bill, the change in CapEx guidance, is that also just foreign exchange effects the translation of the CapEx?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Vast majority of it, Bryan, is, yes.
componenttext: Vast majority of it, Bryan, is, yes.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, when we look at the operating income, the currency neutral operating profit income growth expectation for the year, you held it at mid single-digit, just how much of it was propped up by the reduction in your outlook for cost of goods per
componenttext: Okay. And then, when we look at the operating income, the currency neutral operating profit income growth expectation for the year, you held it at mid single-digit, just how much of it was propped up by the reduction in your outlook for cost of goods per case versus any reductions you made for your full-year SG&A outlook? Was it mostly the cost of goods -- cost per -- cost of goods per case has come in little bit more favorably?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you look at our ability to maintain the operating income growth given what we’ve experienced with the volume shortfall, we’ve managed SG&A very carefully the first half of the year. As I mentioned in my remarks it’s going to be a li
componenttext: Well, I think if you look at our ability to maintain the operating income growth given what we’ve experienced with the volume shortfall, we’ve managed SG&A very carefully the first half of the year. As I mentioned in my remarks it’s going to be a little bit of a tick up in Q3. I think overall, our ability to maintain that operating income growth is probably directionally half and half SG&A, cost control and then favorable cost of goods outlook as well. So it’s both of those delivering against that target.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012

componenttext: And then finally just on the operating income outlook, I guess given what you said about your expectations for currency in the third quarter, reported operating income is going to be down somewhere in the 6% or 7% range I guess, and then it implies that the fourth quarter reported operating income will actually be up and is that partly a function of where costs are going to fall 3Q versus 4Q and also an easier currency comparison, is that part of what goes into that thinking?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012

componenttext: Okay. And then just finally just how volume-dependent is that, it just seems like you’ve had some flexibility in terms of managing cost components in the P&L. When you look into the second half of the year, is it just more volume dependent in terms of achieving the guidance or is there still some flexibility in terms of managing costs?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think there is some flexibility that as we get deeper into the year the ability, just the amount of runway that you have to manage your cost diminishes. So I would say it could become more volume dependent if volume were to continue to be negative. But
componenttext: I think there is some flexibility that as we get deeper into the year the ability, just the amount of runway that you have to manage your cost diminishes. So I would say it could become more volume dependent if volume were to continue to be negative. But right now, we feel comfortable that we’re going to be able to manage that within a normalized weather pattern.

I don’t know if it’s a matter of comparing those retailers where the pricing has been implemented versus those where it hasn’t, but do you have any sense of how your elasticity is playing out versus what’s your models had said it might play out?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, it’s really too early and it’s very difficult to read because basically the way the price has increased is more by channel than by customer. So you would see that it does increase less in the big hypermarkets, the costs will more clear [ph] than f
componenttext: No, it’s really too early and it’s very difficult to read because basically the way the price has increased is more by channel than by customer. So you would see that it does increase less in the big hypermarkets, the costs will more clear [ph] than for example in the supermarkets and for the moment it’s really impossible I think to reach with that figures. But we know by experience that again the elasticity in France was probably much lower than it used to be in other markets. So we need to wait for full quarter with the price increase if it materialize because I’m not excluding that one of the customer will not materialize the totality of the price increase before the end of the year. We’ll see generally summer is a good timing for our customer to increase pricing. We have seen some acceleration in the price transition in the past 2 weeks. We need to wait for that.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: John, you talked a little bit about the difference in the business model in terms of the impact of immediate consumption and relative to the margins in terms of future consumption. I think that highlights sort of the big structural improvement to your ope
componenttext: John, you talked a little bit about the difference in the business model in terms of the impact of immediate consumption and relative to the margins in terms of future consumption. I think that highlights sort of the big structural improvement to your operating model as you spun off the North American assets and went to a distribution light model, a non-DSD model as you moved into Europe. And I guess as we look into your consideration of the Germany business, when I think about some of the brutal de-levering quarters that I’ve seen in terms of the U.S. business in terms of what happens when volumes go south with the big DSD model. And I guess the question becomes why deal with the aggravation of that if we’re going to end up with down quarters and why not just stay with the asset light model that you’ve currently in Western Europe, what’s the advantage of bringing on a DSD business like that?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for the question, John. I don’t really want to make any specific comments around Germany other than to say that at least I think based on public information we’ve seen the DSD piece of the business there is something less than half. So it
componenttext:
Yes, thanks for the question, John. I don’t really want to make any specific comments around Germany other than to say that at least I think based on public information we’ve seen the DSD piece of the business there is something less than half. So it’s not necessarily a surrogate for the U.S. model. But I think you pointed out very well what we’re so excited about and have been all along since this transaction and that is the flexibility that we have in our business model and we reflect back -- some of us to 3 to 4 years ago with some of the challenges we had in other markets, we obviously didn’t have that flexibility because volume -- the volume shortfall and the impact it has on your profitability in certain markets can be huge and so we’re not happy about the volume results we had here in the first half and we’re committed to getting it back on track. But we are pleased that we have the flexibility in our business model to tweak and turn the levers in such a way to come up with a result which is frankly a heck of a lot better than it would have been maybe under other circumstances.
Our final question comes from Priya Ohri-Gupta of Barclays.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Priya Ohri-Gupta. As you move towards your leverage objective over the course of next year, how should we think about the market you plan to issue in? Is it still going to be primarily U.S. or should we expect a greater percentage of that to come from eur
componenttext: Priya Ohri-Gupta. As you move towards your leverage objective over the course of next year, how should we think about the market you plan to issue in? Is it still going to be primarily U.S. or should we expect a greater percentage of that to come from euro or potentially even sterling?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks for your question. We have been very U.S. centric in our debt offerings to-date. I think part of that was because of the state of the European debt markets and the fact that our all-in cost of borrowing in the U.S. was meaningfully lower than it wa
componenttext: Thanks for your question. We have been very U.S. centric in our debt offerings to-date. I think part of that was because of the state of the European debt markets and the fact that our all-in cost of borrowing in the U.S. was meaningfully lower than it was in Europe. Over the recent weeks and months that gap has closed considerably and it’s almost on parity, I think if you look at it today. So going forward, we would be striving to be much more active in the European debt markets and bring more of a balance of euro-issued versus U.S.-issued to our cumulative debt portfolio prospectively.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, thanks again to all of you for joining us today. We are very excited again about being here in London. We appreciate you taking the time to join us and hope that all of you will enjoy the Olympics as much as we will. Take care and have a great
componenttext: Okay. Well, thanks again to all of you for joining us today. We are very excited again about being here in London. We appreciate you taking the time to join us and hope that all of you will enjoy the Olympics as much as we will. Take care and have a great day.
