componenttext: Our next question comes from Priya Ohri-Gupta, with Barclays Capital.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I had a question about your sort of evaluation of capital structure alternative. How should we think about the high end of your previously stated leveraged target? Could we see that moving up as a result of this? And then secondly, could you just remind u
componenttext: I had a question about your sort of evaluation of capital structure alternative. How should we think about the high end of your previously stated leveraged target? Could we see that moving up as a result of this? And then secondly, could you just remind us of what your long term credit rating objective is? Thank you.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Bill, could I ask to you…
componenttext: Okay. Bill, could I ask to you…

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I’ll start with the second part of your question. Our current credit ratings are generally based on what we’ve been articulating consistently for the past couple of years that we intend to operate within the 2.5x to 3x net debt to EBITDA. So whi
componenttext: Sure. I’ll start with the second part of your question. Our current credit ratings are generally based on what we’ve been articulating consistently for the past couple of years that we intend to operate within the 2.5x to 3x net debt to EBITDA. So while we’ve been operating below that, generally the conversation with the credit rating agencies are based on the fact that over time we are going up into that range. So individually, they treat the actual versus the targets slightly differently but I think it’s safe to say that generally we envision operating in the triple B plus range. With the first part of your question, I didn’t follow it completely but again we’ve stated that our long term net debt to EBITDA range is 2.5x to 3x and we would like to get to that by the end of 2013. We would operate within that range over time if we had a meaningful M&A opportunity, could we exceed that 3x for a short period of time and then let the cash flow from the business inclusive of the acquisition bring us back down into that range? That would be the way we would envision that. We don’t see it as a hard cap but neither do we see ourselves exceeding that 3x and then just staying above it and continuing to grow for a meaningful period of time. Did that address your question?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. It was perfect.
componenttext: Yes. It was perfect.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Faucher, with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Faucher, with JP Morgan.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I am going to follow up on this French retailer question again because I guess I am trying to figure out how this will position itself over the next let’s say 6 to 12 months. Is this something where we should expect more over the excise tax pricing impa
componenttext: I am going to follow up on this French retailer question again because I guess I am trying to figure out how this will position itself over the next let’s say 6 to 12 months. Is this something where we should expect more over the excise tax pricing impact to roll though therefore hitting in volume or is it something where we should expect maybe a greater push back on pricing for 2013 in which case you may have a little bit of de-levering on the gross margin line if you can’t the pricing through or is it something else from that standpoint?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hubert?
componenttext: Hubert?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: John, what we expect is to see an improvement in the sense that another increase in the pricing until the end the year but again, as you also know yearly negotiation in France are always pretty important and pretty intense. So it’s always around that ne
componenttext: John, what we expect is to see an improvement in the sense that another increase in the pricing until the end the year but again, as you also know yearly negotiation in France are always pretty important and pretty intense. So it’s always around that negotiation but I think the bulk of the pricing should have been absorbed now in the next 3 to 6 months. It doesn’t mean that we will not have some discretion with the trade because again, the market has been tough so far. But it would be a bit of a combination of them having taken I hope and it’s based on the latest figures, you can see the market some more pricing but it is about to resuming. There is a joint value creation story on the market which still has a huge potential. We really think the consumers are ready to accept some higher level of pricing as long as we come with the right marketing activity which we plan to do for next year. So, yes as always the round of negotiation with the French trade will be probably a difficult moment to pass but I think we have the right plan and the right innovations to come to overcome this period.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then we did see a sequential change in Coke’s price mix performance from Q2 to Q3. So you were down about 600 basis points sequentially. You talked a lot about channel, package etcetera. You guys didn’t really see that bigger of an im
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then we did see a sequential change in Coke’s price mix performance from Q2 to Q3. So you were down about 600 basis points sequentially. You talked a lot about channel, package etcetera. You guys didn’t really see that bigger of an impact in the third quarter. Is there something that’s less impacting your parts of Europe?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: The simple answer is yes, we did not see a significant impact.
componenttext: The simple answer is yes, we did not see a significant impact.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I’ll just jump back in, operator. John, I was going back through the key which will be releasing and we do disclose in there and actually in a little bit more detail than the question you asked. But overall, sparkling was down about 2 percentage points
componenttext: I’ll just jump back in, operator. John, I was going back through the key which will be releasing and we do disclose in there and actually in a little bit more detail than the question you asked. But overall, sparkling was down about 2 percentage points and the Still was up about 13.5 percentage points benefiting from water on the one hand, partially as a result of the Olympics, and then Capri Sun performed very well in Great Britain with the market disruption that we took advantage of during the quarter. So, I hope that answers your question.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, operator lets go to the next question.
componenttext: Okay, operator lets go to the next question.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Swartzberg, with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Swartzberg, with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes. It’s actually a follow up to the comment you just made, Bill. The Stills performance, the 13.5, can you talk about how you see that looking out. Whether this kind of double digit performance is sustainable. How much of that water in the Olympics i
componenttext: Yes. It’s actually a follow up to the comment you just made, Bill. The Stills performance, the 13.5, can you talk about how you see that looking out. Whether this kind of double digit performance is sustainable. How much of that water in the Olympics is the factor. Talk a little bit about the sustainability of this kind of strength that is Still?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We’ll, I‘ll give a couple of comments and then maybe Hubert would want to add to that as well. Quite frankly, it was a little bit of an opportunistic situation of third quarter both with Schweppes Abbey Well being highlighted in the Olympic activity i
componenttext: We’ll, I‘ll give a couple of comments and then maybe Hubert would want to add to that as well. Quite frankly, it was a little bit of an opportunistic situation of third quarter both with Schweppes Abbey Well being highlighted in the Olympic activity in GB. It obviously got boost there, and as I mentioned Capri Sun did very well in GB also because of the market disruption at the product proof sheets being pulled from market for a number of weeks. So, are we going to be able to benefit from that same level of opportunity in the fourth quarter in 2013? I think not. Having said that, I think it’s an opportunity for consumers to have experienced our product and hopefully it will be an opportunity that we can leverage going forward to maintain some growth but to extrapolate double-digit growth going forward probably a little aggressive.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Hubert, you want to add to.
componenttext: Hubert, you want to add to.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just to add on what Bill said, we have been very pleased with the impact of the Olympics on our Still portfolio especially on Glaceau, and especially in GB we have seen an acceleration of our equipment, an acceleration of our growth and I think the bulk o
componenttext: Just to add on what Bill said, we have been very pleased with the impact of the Olympics on our Still portfolio especially on Glaceau, and especially in GB we have seen an acceleration of our equipment, an acceleration of our growth and I think the bulk of that will stay in the last quarter because we have attached new consumer for the brand and the same can be said for Abbey Well. But again, the one shot on Capri in GB will not repeat itself. However, we can say that we see a very positive trend on the Continent of Capri-Sun but probably not to the level we have enjoyed in Q3.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: That’s great. And if I could follow on I guess a related question. I may have missed it but are you guys comfortable telling us how trends have performed and more recently on a total CC basis in October?
componenttext: That’s great. And if I could follow on I guess a related question. I may have missed it but are you guys comfortable telling us how trends have performed and more recently on a total CC basis in October?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just, I think what we’d say is the business is performing in line with our if you want to call it revised expectations and I think that’s probably about as much as we could say now it’s as we expected.
componenttext: Just, I think what we’d say is the business is performing in line with our if you want to call it revised expectations and I think that’s probably about as much as we could say now it’s as we expected.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally on the works' council’s process, I don't know much about it. It characterizes a long process. I guess simple question, the folks that are represented, the employees of CC who are represented by these work’s councils’. Are they
componenttext: Okay. And then finally on the works' council’s process, I don't know much about it. It characterizes a long process. I guess simple question, the folks that are represented, the employees of CC who are represented by these work’s councils’. Are they also represented by bottlers of Coke products in non-CCE territories? In other words is there a factor here where you are kind of working with Coke Cola because it’s not only a purely CCE territory issue?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. these are purely CCE employees and CCE employee’s representative and it has not interaction with neither any of the Coke bottler or the Coca Cola Company. So, it’s pure CCE matter inside this who are council.
componenttext: No. these are purely CCE employees and CCE employee’s representative and it has not interaction with neither any of the Coke bottler or the Coca Cola Company. So, it’s pure CCE matter inside this who are council.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrew Holland, of SG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Holland, of SG.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just final clarification if I may on the $100 million. You talked about the phasing is that? Can I just be clear that you don’t expect any of that to drop to the bottom line? All of that has been earmarked for reinvestment. Is that the case?
componenttext: Just final clarification if I may on the $100 million. You talked about the phasing is that? Can I just be clear that you don’t expect any of that to drop to the bottom line? All of that has been earmarked for reinvestment. Is that the case?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. what we said is that we’ll generate on a ratable basis. A third, a third, a third over each of those years and we will use those funds I think as we see best fit to do so whether it’s reinvesting in the business, de-risking our P&L or frankly drop
componenttext: No. what we said is that we’ll generate on a ratable basis. A third, a third, a third over each of those years and we will use those funds I think as we see best fit to do so whether it’s reinvesting in the business, de-risking our P&L or frankly dropping it into the bottom line. All of those are opportunities that we will consider and we will do it as we move forward.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: But I think, Andrew, it is fair to assume that the totality of it would not drop to bottom line. Incremental.
componenttext: But I think, Andrew, it is fair to assume that the totality of it would not drop to bottom line. Incremental.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, now I certainly understand that. And you’ve been very clear on that. I am just - my impression was that none of it would drop to the bottom line. You now seem to be suggesting that some it might. Can you give an idea of how much of it might?
componenttext: Yes, now I certainly understand that. And you’ve been very clear on that. I am just - my impression was that none of it would drop to the bottom line. You now seem to be suggesting that some it might. Can you give an idea of how much of it might?

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: No. We are not in a position to do that because again it’s going to be really depending on how our business is performing. What the macroeconomics are looking like. How much do we want invest in various technologies that Hubert talked about. So no, it w
componenttext: No. We are not in a position to do that because again it’s going to be really depending on how our business is performing. What the macroeconomics are looking like. How much do we want invest in various technologies that Hubert talked about. So no, it will be a year-by-year choice.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: As we continue to move forward both in implementing of plans and the passage of time, we’ll be more clear about how much of any of that is going to be dropping to the bottom line on an annual ongoing basis.
componenttext: As we continue to move forward both in implementing of plans and the passage of time, we’ll be more clear about how much of any of that is going to be dropping to the bottom line on an annual ongoing basis.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just going back to an issue that was raised by Ian a little earlier on the Briffick Bar merger. He was asking specifically about pricing. I just wonder if there’s any other possible impacts positive or negative for your business that you would
componenttext: Okay. And just going back to an issue that was raised by Ian a little earlier on the Briffick Bar merger. He was asking specifically about pricing. I just wonder if there’s any other possible impacts positive or negative for your business that you would anticipate as a result of that merger assuming it goes through.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I don’t, really we’d be in a position to comment on that. That merger of course we’ve read about. They ask for more time and they’ve gotten it and we’ll see if it goes through. We view ourselves as a very significant and successful competitor in
componenttext: I don’t, really we’d be in a position to comment on that. That merger of course we’ve read about. They ask for more time and they’ve gotten it and we’ll see if it goes through. We view ourselves as a very significant and successful competitor in that market and we have 2 significant competitors and if they combine we will have one and we’ll do just as well going forward as we have in the past. Now, we would not want to speculate on what would change because we tend to spend most of our time thinking offensively, not trying to react to what competition’s doing.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: And operator, we’ve got time for one more question.
componenttext: And operator, we’ve got time for one more question.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from Bryan Spillane, of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our final question comes from Bryan Spillane, of Bank of America.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: I have got a follow up I guess to Judy’s question earlier about just how the change in the macro environment might be affecting the way you are thinking about investment. I guess more specifically M&A, to the extent that you are contemplating expansion
componenttext: I have got a follow up I guess to Judy’s question earlier about just how the change in the macro environment might be affecting the way you are thinking about investment. I guess more specifically M&A, to the extent that you are contemplating expansion in Europe; you are contemplating M&A. How does just the change in the macro environment and kind of what we are dealing with today versus what the outlook was and what the macro environment was when  CC in its current form was formed. Has that affected at all the way you think about M&A, the way you think about risk, pricing risk. Just any color on that at all would be helpful.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: We’ll, let me just say our view about M&A and our disciplined approach to it hasn’t changed. We’ve had the same view all along and we will remain -- continue to have that kind of very thoughtful disciplined careful approach. There’s not just one m
componenttext: We’ll, let me just say our view about M&A and our disciplined approach to it hasn’t changed. We’ve had the same view all along and we will remain -- continue to have that kind of very thoughtful disciplined careful approach. There’s not just one metric we look, as we've, I think, indicated before there are a whole host of items that would enter into our basket of considerations and at the end of the day the most important question would be can we create value for our shareholders going forward. It is really is about that simple. There’s the macroeconomic situation dramatically changing anything? The answer is categorically no. Is it one more factor that we have to put it into our basket of consideration particularly when you consider the other things that could happen because of macroeconomic challenges? Then the answer is sure. It would be one more thing that we would need to look at but again I think the simple answer to your question is macroeconomics in general it does not change our disciplined approach but it would be one consideration that we would factor into the basket.

headline: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Oct 25, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And thanks to all of you for joining us today. We really appreciated you taking the time to be part of this discussion. And we wish you a very good day. Thanks.
componenttext: Okay. And thanks to all of you for joining us today. We really appreciated you taking the time to be part of this discussion. And we wish you a very good day. Thanks.
